context: <a0_0>Clay models of ducks found in China <b5_0>dating back to 4000 BC<b5_0/> may indicate the domestication of ducks took place there during the Yangshao culture<a0_0/>. Even if this is not the case, <a1_0>domestication of the duck <b6_0>took place in the Far East at least 1500 years earlier than in the West<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Lucius Columella, writing in the first century BC, advised those who sought to rear ducks to <a2_0><b7_0>collect wildfowl eggs and put them under a broody hen<b7_0/>,<a2_0/> because when raised in this way, the ducks "lay aside their wild nature and without hesitation breed when shut up in the bird pen". Despite this, <a3_0>ducks did not appear in agricultural texts in Western Europe until <b8_0>about 810 AD<b8_0/><a3_0/>, when they began to be <a4_0>mentioned alongside geese, chickens, and peafowl as being used for rental payments made by tenants to landowners.
